name: rare earth element mine operation and beneficiation, bastnaesite and monazite ore | rare earth oxide concentrate, 50% REO | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22675/documentation

This dataset refers to the mining (open pit mining) and beneficiation (two step beneficiation process including ball milling and magnetic separation) activities, in order to produce 1 kg of rare earth oxide (REO) concentrate, 50% beneficiated, from the extracted monazite and bastnaesite minerals in the Bayan obo mines. China is the top producer of Rare Earth metals in the world, being responsible for approximately 81.4% of the global production (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf). ;This dataset is based on the Critical Materials Life Cycle Assessment Tool (CMLCAT), an excel based software that complements the publication of Arshi et al (2018) (reference 1), which contains the LCI data for each subprocess mentioned in the publication. The amounts of the byproducts iron concentrate and rare earth tailings were taken from the Wang et al (2020) publication (reference 2).;The produced rare earth concentrate will then undergo acid roasting, water leaching & chlorine conversion, solvent extraction and calcination in order to produce high purity individual lanthanum oxide, cerium oxide, neodymium oxide and a mixed samarium-europium gadolinium concentrate (outside of this system boundaries).;;Reference 1: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484.;;Reference 2: Wang, L., Jiao, G., Lu, H., & Wang, Q. (2019). Life cycle assessment of integrated exploitation technology for tailings in Bayan Obo Mine, China. Applied Ecology and Environmental Research, 17, 4343-4359. doi:10.15666/aeer/1702_43434359

The activity starts with the mining of the mixed monazite and bastnasite ores.

The activity ends with the production of rare earth concentrate, 50% beneficiated.

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

location.name: China, Inner Mongol (内蒙古自治区)

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The Bayon Obo mine is located in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, on the northern edge of the North China Kraton, approximately 150km northwest of Baotou and serves as the world's largest REE mine (both in terms of reserves and production). The Bayan Obo reserves were discovered in 1927 while the REEs were discovered in 1935 and contains more than 100 million tonnes of proven REE reserves (accounting for more than 80% of the REE reserves in China). The Bayan Obo ore consists of more than 100 minerals with the principal rare earth mineral ores being monazite and bastnaesite with the ratio of bastnasite to monazite in the ore being 7:3 by mass.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Firstly, open pit, mining (drilling and blasting) is performed in order to obtain the iron ore and a minor quantity of rare earth ores (5−6 % rare earth oxide equivalent). Then, a two-step beneficiation process is applied to produce the REO concentrate. In the first step, ball milling and magnetic separation is used for the isolation of the iron ore. In the second step, the resulting REO tailing (containing monazite and bastnasite), is processed to get a 50% REO equivalent concentrate via flotation.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The original mining inventory was obtained from - Sprecher, B., Xiao, Y., Walton, A., Speight, J., Harris, R., Kleijn, R., . . . Kramer, G. J. (2014). Life cycle inventory of the production of rare earths and the subsequent production of NdFeB rare earth permanent magnets. Environ Sci Technol, 48(7), 3951-3958. doi:10.1021/es404596q - which was based on the Ecoinvent dataset for iron mining. Environmental flows of rare earths were added according to the authors of the publication.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset is based on the following publication: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484.  All exchanges from/ to the environment and from/to the technosphere were calculated using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university. This excel-based software acts as a supporting tool to the abovementioned publication. Exception to this case is the calculation of the amount of the individual metals and gangue materials that were mined from the ground as well as the amounts of the produced byproducts. The abovementioned exchanges have been calculated based on various sources and their calculation is reported analytically on the general comments of the respective exchanges. Individual exchanges such as rare earth tailings, wastewater and gangue which were not contained in the original datasets have been added for completeness purposes and their calculation is based on mass balance.

location.name: China, Inner Mongol (内蒙古自治区)

flow.name: rare earth oxide concentrate, 50% REO
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

exchanges.description: Value has been recalculated, due to the presence of more recent and accurate data. The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Iron content in the Bayan Obo ore is 33% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536) and ii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

exchanges.description: Value has been recalculated, due to the presence of more recent and accurate data. The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Rare earth oxide (REO) content in the Bayan Obo ore is 6% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536), ii) 23% of the REOs consists of Lanthanum oxide and (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf Table 2, page 10) and iii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

flow.name: Uranium-238
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: The original value (production of 2.5E+08 kg of concentrate results in the production of 3.8618E+09 kg of rare earth tailings) - after adjustment to represent the production of tailings per 1 kg of produced concentrate  is 15.4472 kg. The values in parentheses were taken from the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464. Value was not originally contained in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure), from which the majority of the exchanges were taken. The amount has been slightly reduced for mass balance purposes, which leads to minor underestimation of the annual production volume.

Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464) and ii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (same source as above). iii) the subtotal masses of Sc2O3 are: Nb:65.20%, O:34.80% (Source: https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

exchanges.description: Value has been calculated by subtracting the sum of the amount of the individual metals that were extracted from the ground (i.e, Iron, Cerium, Lanthanum, Neodymium, Praseodymium, Samarium, Gadolinium, Europium, Scandium, Niobium) from the amount of ore that is required for the production of 1 kg of Rare Earth concentrate (nearly 24 kg). Value was not originally contained in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure), from which the majority of the exchanges were taken and has been assumed for completeness purposes.Value has been incresed by 0.040174 kg for mass balance purposes.

The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Rare earth oxide (REO) content in the Bayan Obo ore is 6% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536), ii) 0.20% of the REOs consists of Europium oxide and (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf Table 2, page 10) and iii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

location.name: China, Inner Mongol (内蒙古自治区)

flow.name: Europium
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description: Value has been recalculated, due to the presence of more recent and accurate data. The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Rare earth oxide (REO) content in the Bayan Obo ore is 6% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536), ii) 18.5% of the REOs consists of Neodymium oxide and (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf Table 2, page 10) and iii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

exchanges.description: Value taken from the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure) and adjusted from the original dataset to correspond to the production of 1 kg of REO concentrate.

exchanges.description: Value has been recalculated, due to the presence of more recent and accurate data. The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Rare earth oxide (REO) content in the Bayan Obo ore is 6% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536), ii) 50% of the REOs consists of Cerium oxide and (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf Table 2, page 10) and iii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

exchanges.description: 1.02E-01 m3 of water consumption stems from the mining process, 2.22E-02 m3 from the the iron separation process and the rest (3.55E-03 m3)  from the rare earth oxide concentration process. Value adjusted from the original dataset to correspond to the production of 1 kg of REO concentrate.

exchanges.description: Value has been recalculated, due to the presence of more recent and accurate data. The calculation is based on the following facts: i) Rare earth oxide (REO) content in the Bayan Obo ore is 6% (Source: Koltun, P., & Tharumarajah, A. (2014). Life Cycle Impact of Rare Earth Elements. ISRN Metallurgy, 2014, 907536. doi:10.1155/2014/907536), ii) 0.80% of the REOs consists of Samarium oxide and (Source: https://prd-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2017-raree.pdf Table 2, page 10) and iii) after adjustment of the reported values to represent the production of 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content, nearly 24 kg of Bayan Obo ore is required to produce 1 kg of rare earth concentrate, 50% REO content. (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value reported on the original dataset provided in the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018) has not been considered.

Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure) and adjusted from the original dataset to correspond to the production of 1 kg of REO concentrate.
